review.title: From 3D Point Clouds To Semantic Objects An Ontology-Based Detection Approach
review.abstract: This paper presents a knowledge-based detection of objects approach using the OWL ontology language, the Semantic Web Rule Language, and 3D processing built-ins aiming at combining geometrical analysis of 3D point clouds and specialist's knowledge. This combination allows the detection and the annotation of objects contained in point clouds. The context of the study is the detection of railway objects such as signals, technical cupboards, electric poles, etc. Thus, the resulting enriched and populated ontology, that contains the annotations of objects in the point clouds, is used to feed a GIS systems or an IFC file for architecture purposes.

sections.text: This section consists of two parts: The first part deals with the recognition strategies for geometric modeling and object recognition described in the literature; the second part is knowledge modeling, which is of value to our strategy.

sections.heading: 2.1 Detection strategies
sections.text: Today, scene modeling is largely a manual process that is time-consuming and subjective. While there is a clear need for automated or even semi-automated methods to simplify scenario creation, research on the subject is still in the very early stages. This review shows that many of the existing methods for geometric modeling and object recognition can be important for process automation. Three main strategies are described in the literature, the first being based on human interaction with supplied software for point cloud classification and annotation, while the second strategy relies more on automated data processing without human interaction through the use of different segmentation techniques for feed extraction, new techniques represent an improvement over those cited by integrating semantic networks to guide the reconstruction process.

sections.heading: 2.2 Knowledge modelling
sections.text: In recent years, formal ontology has been proposed as a solution to the problem of reconstructing 3D objects from 3D dot clouds (Cruz, Marzani, & Boochs, 2007).In this area, the ontology structure has been defined as a formal representation of knowledge through a series of concepts within a domain, and the relationships between these concepts. It is used to puzzle over the entities within that domain, and can be used to describe the domain. Conventionally, ontology presents a "formal, explicit specification of a common conceptualization" (Gruber, 2005).Ontology provides a common vocabulary that can be used to model a domain. Well-made ontology has a number of positive aspects, such as the ability to define a precise vocabulary of terms, the ability to inherit and expand relationships, the relationships between defined languages, and finally the ability to explain relationships between defined concepts.

sections.heading: 3.1 Ontology schema
sections.text: This section discusses the various aspects related to the ontology structure behind the WiDOP prototype in order to respond to the various purposes cited. Ontology presents the core of the WiDOP project and provides a knowledge base for the application created. However, the global schema of the modeled ontology structure provides a suitable framework to characterize the various captured objects from the point of view of 3D processing. The generated ontology is mainly used for two purposes: conducting the processing algorithm sequence creation based on the target object. To facilitate the semantic annotation of the different captured objects within the target group, the ontology is divided into three main parts: the algorithm conceiving concepts and the geometry sequence creation based on the target object properties. However, they are linked to other captured objects within the target scene objects.

sections.heading: 4 DOMAIN KNOWLEDGE MODELLING
sections.text: The resulting knowledge base around the Deutsche Bahn scene was inspired by our discussion with the domain expert and our study based on the official website of the Deutsche Bahn specification "http: / / stellwerke.de." Once it is complete, new knowledge about the geometry and metrological relationships between the various elements will be synthesized. An overview of the elements targeted, the most useful and discriminatory features for their detection and interaction, is available. Basically, a railway signal is one of the most important elements within the Deutsche Bahn scene, where we find main signals and secondary signals. Main signals are divided into primary signals and long-distance signals. In fact, the primary signal is a railway signal. It indicates whether the subsequent track section may be traveled. Normally, a primary signal is announced by a long-distance signal, the latter indicating which image signal is to be expected to be linked to the main signal at a distance of 1 km. Large variety of secondary signals are presented from each other, as are the preceding electrical elements, each of the other, and each of the other.

sections.heading: 4.1 Geometric characteristics
sections.text: Geometric characteristics can be a discriminatory feature that can improve the automatic annotation process. Therefore, we decide to examine the various geometric characteristics related to the cited elements and then use only the discriminatory characteristic as the basic feature for a particular object. In a first step, Bounding Boxes are used to focus on topological relationships. The following table groups the object characteristics in relation to the properties of a Bounding Box (Figure 5). This table is extended by algorithmic characteristics, but not presented here.

sections.heading: 4.2 Topologic characteristics
sections.text: During the exploration of the railway area, many standard rules are imposed to help the driver and ensure the safety of the passengers. In our view, these are also helpful for checking and guiding the annotation process: for example, the distance between the long-distance signal and the main signal corresponds to the braking distance that the trains need. The braking distance is to be determined on a specific route and is often 1000 m in the main lines or 700 m in rare cases. In addition, three to five approach signal shafts are about 75 m away, while the last one is then 100 m away from the long-distance signal, Figure 6. The same applies to the mast elements, as they are usually 50 m apart from each other. In addition, an important additional information that can distinguish the masts from the signal is connected to the small power box, which is always connected to the signal bottom.In the next section, an overview of the procedure undertaken in the WiDOP project for recognizing and commenting the various objects of Deutsche Bahn is given.

sections.heading: 6 CASE STUDY
sections.text: For the demonstration of our system, 500 metres away from the scanned point clouds associated with the Deutsche Bahn 67 scene in the city of Nuremberg, a large number of target objects were scanned using a terrestrial laser scanner, which was fixed within a train, resulting in a large point cloud representing the surfaces of the scene objects.Various rules are processed, firstly, all vertical elements in the area of interest are searched, and then topological relationships between the captured geometries are qualified, followed by further comments on aspects that express facts about the orientation or size of the elements, which may be sufficient to finalise a decision on the semantics of an object or facts that express topological relationships or both of themes.This second step within our approach is aimed at identifying existing topologies between the captured geometries by testing useful topologies for geometric annotations L.

sections.heading: 7 CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: We have proposed a new solution for the detection of objects from technical surveys within laser scanning technology, which performs the detection of objects in 3D point clouds by using existing knowledge about a specific area (DB). This knowledge modelled under the ontology SWFL rules is used to comment on the execution of 3D processing, topological qualification and finally the detected elements to enrich ontology and advance the detection of new objects. Future work will include the integration of new knowledge that can intervene within the annotation process, such as the number of detected lines within each boundary field and the updating of the general platform architecture to ensure more communication between scene knowledge within 3D processing.
